title: 108_hr1681
content: The "Veterans Claims Continuation Act" allows for the continuation of claims and substitution of parties upon the death of the applicant for benefits. The "Veterans Claims Continuation Act" permits the continuation of claims and substitution of parties when an applicant for benefits dies before a final decision is made on their claim. The "Veterans Claims Continuation Act" allows for the substitution of parties in claims when the applicant dies before a final decision is reached. An eligible person, such as the surviving spouse, children over 21, surviving parent, executor, or heirs of the veteran, can submit an application to be substituted as the claimant. If multiple individuals apply, the eligible person is determined in a specific order. Upon the death of a claimant, the Secretary can substitute an eligible person to represent the deceased claimant's interests. The Secretary must notify the estate and authorized representative of the deceased claimant. If multiple individuals apply, the first to submit the application or motion will be considered the eligible person. Upon the death of a claimant, the Secretary can substitute an eligible person to represent the deceased claimant's interests. The substitute claimant must file an application within one year of the claimant's death or within six months of notification. The substitute claimant will have the same rights and responsibilities as the original claimant. If benefits are awarded, they will be paid accordingly. Upon the death of a claimant, benefits will be paid to specific beneficiaries in the following order: 1) veteran's spouse, children, and dependent parents, 2) surviving children of a deceased veteran, 3) surviving parents of a child of a veteran, and 4) decedent's estate if no eligible beneficiaries are found. Upon the death of a claimant, benefits will be paid to specific beneficiaries in a specific order, including the decedent's estate if no eligible beneficiaries are found. The Secretary will appoint a substitute claimant if needed, who must provide necessary evidence within one year to receive benefits. The term 'payee' in section 5112(b) includes a deceased claimant with a substitute claimant appointed. SEC. 3. Payment of accrued benefits for deaths before enactment. Section 5121 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to pay accrued benefits of deceased individuals who died before the enactment of the Veterans Claims Continuation Act for up to two years. Accrued benefits are defined as benefits due to a deceased individual. The term 'accrued benefits' refers to periodic monetary benefits under laws administered by the Secretary that a deceased individual was entitled to at the time of death. SEC. 4. SUBSTITUTION OF SURVIVOR IN CASES PENDING BEFORE A COURT. Subchapter II of chapter 72 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow for substitution of parties in cases pending before a court if a claimant dies before filing an appeal. An eligible person may file an appeal as a substituted claimant within the specified time period. If an appellant or respondent dies while a claim is pending before a court, an eligible person may move the court for substitution of claimant. The motion must be filed within the prescribed time period. The amendment allows for substitution of parties in cases pending before a court if a claimant dies before filing an appeal. An eligible person may move the court for substitution within the specified time period. If a final decision has not been made, an eligible person can be appointed to continue the prosecution or defense of the claim. The table of sections in the subchapter is amended to include a new item related to substitution of parties in court cases when a claimant dies before filing an appeal. Section 7270 of title 38, United States Code allows for substitution of parties in court cases when a claimant dies. This section applies to deaths of claimants on or after the enactment of the Act.
